question: Who was the first Turk invader of India after Muhammad bin Qasim (Arab invader)?
solution:
• The first Turk invader of India after Muhammad bin Qasim (the Arab general) was Subuktagin, the father of Mahmud of Ghazni.
  • He was the founder of the Ghaznavid dynasty and initiated invasions into northwestern India, particularly targeting the Hindu Shahi rulers in the late 10th century.
  • These early invasions laid the groundwork for Mahmud Ghaznavi’s more extensive campaigns into India.
  • Subuktagin's military campaigns marked the beginning of Turk invasions which later evolved into permanent Muslim rule in India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (a) Subuktagin.

Additional Information:

  • Alptegin, Subuktagin’s master, was also a key figure but never invaded India directly.
  • Bakhtiar Khilji came much later, during the 12th–13th century, known for conquering Bengal and Bihar.

question: Which Indian ruler was defeated by the Turks first?
solution:
• The first Indian ruler defeated by the Turks was Raja Jaipal, the ruler of the Hindu Shahi dynasty in present-day Afghanistan and northwestern India.
  • He was defeated by Subuktagin, and later, his son Anandpal was also defeated by Mahmud of Ghazni.
  • Raja Jaipal’s defeat marked the beginning of Turkish invasions into the Indian subcontinent in the late 10th century.
  • This defeat weakened the Hindu Shahi kingdom and opened the gateway for further Islamic conquests in northern India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Jaipal.

Additional Information:

  • Raja Jaipal ruled over Lahore and Kabul regions.
  • After his defeat, he committed self-immolation due to shame and responsibility.

question: Mahmud Ghaznavi attacked India a total of 17 times from 1000 AD to 1027 AD. What was the purpose of so many of his attacks?
option_3: Taking revenge for the death of his father
option_4: Helping Hindushahi ruler Jaipal
solution:
• Mahmud of Ghazni attacked India 17 times between 1000 AD and 1027 AD, and the main purpose of these repeated invasions was looting the immense wealth of Indian temples and cities.
  • He targeted rich temples like Somnath, and cities like Mathura and Kannauj, aiming to finance his empire and military back in Ghazni.
  • Mahmud did not attempt to establish a permanent empire in India; instead, his focus remained on plundering treasures and spreading the glory of Islam through military victories.
  • He returned to Ghazni after every raid with enormous riches, using it to strengthen his capital and cultural institutions.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Looting wealth.

Additional Information:

  • The Somnath temple in Gujarat was one of his most famous targets in 1025 AD, where he carried back enormous wealth.
  • His raids also helped in weakening North Indian kingdoms, paving the way for future invasions.

question: Who was the ruler of Gujarat at the time of attack on Somnath temple in 1025–26 AD?
solution:
• During Mahmud Ghaznavi's attack on the Somnath temple in 1025–26 AD, the ruler of Gujarat was Bhimdev I (Bhim I) of the Solanki (Chaulukya) dynasty.
  • Bhim I was relatively young at the time and could not organize strong resistance against Mahmud’s well-prepared army.
  • The Somnath temple, one of the richest and most revered temples in India, was looted and destroyed by Mahmud during this invasion.
  • This raid was one of Mahmud’s most famous campaigns, as he returned to Ghazni with massive wealth and temple treasures.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (d) Bhim I.

Additional Information:

  • Bhim I later helped in the reconstruction of the Somnath temple with the support of other rulers.
  • The Solanki dynasty ruled Gujarat from the 10th to 13th century and was known for temple architecture and regional stability.

question: Mahmud Ghaznavi's last campaign was in 1027 AD?
solution:
• Mahmud Ghaznavi’s last campaign in India was conducted in 1027 AD, and it was directed against the Jats of the Sindh region.
  • The Jats had attacked his army while he was returning from the famous Somnath temple raid in 1025–26 AD.
  • In retaliation, Mahmud launched a punitive expedition to punish them for looting his caravan and obstructing his return.
  • This campaign was not aimed at conquest, but rather to suppress local resistance and assert his power.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (d) On Jats.

Additional Information:

  • After this campaign, Mahmud never returned to India and died in 1030 AD.
  • The Jats were known for their guerrilla resistance in the Sindh region.

question: Which famous writer came to India with Mahmud Ghaznavi at the time of his invasion?
solution:
• The famous Persian scholar and writer who accompanied Mahmud Ghaznavi during his invasions of India was Alberuni (Al-Biruni).
  • Alberuni was a renowned polymath—a scholar of astronomy, mathematics, history, religion, and languages.
  • During his stay in India, he studied Hindu religion, Sanskrit texts, and Indian sciences, resulting in his famous work “Tahqiq-i-Hind” (later known as Tarikh-ul-Hind).
  • His account is a neutral and detailed observation of Indian society, making it one of the most valuable sources of early 11th-century India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Alberuni.

Additional Information:

  • Alberuni learned Sanskrit to better understand Indian scriptures.
  • His writings cover philosophy, geography, customs, astronomy, and social structure of India.

question: What was the name of Firdausi's composition?
solution:
• The famous Persian poet Firdausi is best known for his epic composition “Shahnama” (Book of Kings).
  • The Shahnama is a long epic poem that recounts the mythological and historical past of Persia (Iran) from the creation of the world up to the Islamic conquest.
  • It was written in Persian and completed around 1010 AD, under the patronage of Mahmud of Ghazni, though Firdausi later became critical of him.
  • The Shahnama is considered one of the greatest literary works of the Persian language.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (a) Shahnama.

Additional Information:

  • The Shahnama contains over 50,000 verses and preserves pre-Islamic Iranian culture.
  • Firdausi spent over 30 years composing it.

question:
With reference to the Ghaznavid Empire, consider the following statement:
  1. They were of Turkish descent.
  2. The Ghaznavid Empire was established by Mahmud Ghazni.

Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
solution:
• Statement 1: They were of Turkish descent – ✅Correct.

    The Ghaznavid dynasty was of Turkish origin. Its founder, Alptegin, and his successor Subuktagin (father of Mahmud of Ghazni), were originally Turkish slaves who rose to power.

  • Statement 2: The Ghaznavid Empire was established by Mahmud Ghazni – ❌Incorrect.

    The Ghaznavid Empire was founded by Subuktagin in the late 10th century. Mahmud of Ghazni later expanded the empire significantly, but he did not establish it.

  • Therefore, only Statement 1 is correct.

Correct Answer: (a) 1 only

Additional Information:

  • Mahmud of Ghazni made Ghazni (in present-day Afghanistan) a major cultural and military center.
  • The Ghaznavid Empire played a key role in early Islamic invasions of India, especially in the northwestern region.

question:
Given below are two statements, one is labeled as Assertion (A) and the other as Reason (R).

Assertion (A): Turkish invasions on India were successful.

Reason (R): There was no political unity in North India.

Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
option_1: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A).
option_2: Both (A) and (R) are true, but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A).
option_3: (A) is true, but (R) is false.
option_4: (A) is false, but (R) is true.
solution:
• Assertion (A): Turkish invasions on India were successful – ✅True

    The Turkish invasions, led by rulers like Mahmud of Ghazni and Muhammad Ghori, were indeed successful. They overcame several Indian rulers and laid the foundation for Muslim rule in India.

  • Reason (R): There was no political unity in North India – ✅True

    During the time of Turkish invasions, North India was fragmented into small kingdoms and often engaged in internal conflicts, which made them vulnerable to external invasions.

  • The lack of political unity was a major reason for the success of the Turks, who were more organized and had strong leadership and cavalry-based armies.
  • Therefore, both (A) and (R) are true, and (R) correctly explains (A).

Correct Answer: (a) Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A).

Additional Information:

  • Indian rulers often failed to unite against a common enemy, unlike the cohesive and strategic Turkish forces.
  • The defeat of Prithviraj Chauhan in the Second Battle of Tarain (1192) is a prime example of disunity among Indian rulers.

question: Who was the first Turkish invader to attack India in the 11th century?
solution:
• The first Turkish invader to attack India in the 11th century was Mahmud of Ghazni.
  • He launched 17 invasions between 1000 and 1027 AD, primarily targeting rich temples and cities in northwestern India.
  • Mahmud's invasions were largely motivated by wealth, and he did not aim to establish a permanent empire in India.
  • His most famous attack was on the Somnath temple in Gujarat in 1025 AD.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (a) Mahmud of Ghazni.

Additional Information:

  • Mahmud was the ruler of the Ghaznavid dynasty, based in present-day Afghanistan.
  • His repeated raids weakened Indian kingdoms and paved the way for future conquests by others like Muhammad Ghori.

question: Mahmud of Ghazni attacked India primarily to:
option_3: Loot wealth and temples
solution:
• Mahmud of Ghazni attacked India primarily with the objective of looting the immense wealth stored in Indian temples and cities.
  • His invasions were not for territorial conquest or permanent rule but for economic gain and to finance his empire in Ghazni (present-day Afghanistan).
  • He targeted rich temples like Somnath, Mathura, and Kannauj, returning with vast treasures each time.
  • While he did promote Islam, his chief motive remained economic plunder, not religious conversion or political domination.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Loot wealth and temples.

Additional Information:

  • Mahmud invaded India 17 times between 1000 and 1027 AD.
  • His raids weakened Indian kingdoms and exposed their disunity, making future invasions easier.

question: How many times did Mahmud of Ghazni invade India?
solution:
• Mahmud of Ghazni invaded India a total of 17 times between 1000 AD and 1027 AD.
  • His campaigns targeted rich temples and cities such as Somnath, Mathura, and Kannauj, and were largely driven by the motive of looting wealth.
  • These repeated invasions were not aimed at establishing permanent rule in India but rather to finance his empire in Ghazni.
  • His consistent success was aided by the lack of political unity among Indian rulers.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) 17 times.

Additional Information:

  • His first invasion began in 1000 AD, and his final campaign was in 1027 AD against the Jats of Sindh.
  • Mahmud’s invasions weakened Indian kingdoms and set the stage for future Muslim conquests.

question: Mahmud of Ghazni's most famous plunder was of the Somnath temple in:
solution:
• Mahmud of Ghazni’s most famous plunder was the attack on the Somnath temple, which took place in 1025 AD.
  • The temple was located in Gujarat, and it was one of the richest and most revered Hindu temples of that time.
  • Mahmud looted immense wealth from the temple and destroyed its structure, carrying the treasures back to Ghazni (in present-day Afghanistan).
  • This raid is remembered as one of the most significant and symbolic attacks during his 17 invasions of India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (a) Gujarat.

Additional Information:

  • The Somnath temple was rebuilt multiple times after the invasion.
  • The present-day Somnath temple was reconstructed after India’s independence and is now a major pilgrimage site.

question: Muhammad Ghori defeated Prithviraj Chauhan in which battle?
option_1: First Battle of Panipat
option_3: First Battle of Tarain
option_4: Second Battle of Tarain
solution:
• Muhammad Ghori defeated Prithviraj Chauhan in the Second Battle of Tarain, which took place in 1192 AD.
  • In the First Battle of Tarain (1191 AD), Prithviraj Chauhan had defeated Muhammad Ghori.
  • However, Ghori returned the next year with a stronger army and defeated Prithviraj in the Second Battle, marking a turning point in Indian history.
  • This victory laid the foundation for Muslim rule in North India, eventually leading to the establishment of the Delhi Sultanate.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (d) Second Battle of Tarain.

Additional Information:

  • After his victory, Muhammad Ghori appointed Qutb-ud-din Aibak as his representative in India.
  • The battle took place near Thanesar (modern-day Haryana).

question: The First Battle of Tarain (1191) was won by:
solution:
• The First Battle of Tarain was fought in 1191 AD between Prithviraj Chauhan and Muhammad Ghori.
  • In this battle, Prithviraj Chauhan emerged victorious, defeating Muhammad Ghori and forcing him to retreat.
  • Ghori was seriously wounded in the battle and barely escaped with his life.
  • However, this victory was short-lived as Ghori returned the following year and defeated Prithviraj in the Second Battle of Tarain (1192 AD).
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (d) Prithviraj Chauhan.

Additional Information:

  • The battles of Tarain were fought near Thanesar in present-day Haryana.
  • These battles played a crucial role in the establishment of Muslim rule in Northern India.

question: Muhammad Ghori laid the foundation of Turkish rule in India by defeating:
solution:
• Muhammad Ghori laid the foundation of Turkish rule in India by defeating Prithviraj Chauhan in the Second Battle of Tarain (1192 AD).
  • This victory allowed him to gain control over Delhi and Ajmer, two important political centers in North India.
  • After his conquest, Ghori appointed his general Qutb-ud-din Aibak to administer the Indian territories.
  • This marked the beginning of Turkish and later Delhi Sultanate rule in India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Prithviraj Chauhan.

Additional Information:

  • After Ghori’s death, Qutb-ud-din Aibak became the first Sultan of Delhi in 1206 AD.
  • This event is regarded as the true beginning of Muslim rule in India.

question: Which of the following Turkish rulers was responsible for appointing Qutb-ud-din Aibak as his viceroy in India?
solution:
• Muhammad Ghori was the Turkish ruler who appointed Qutb-ud-din Aibak as his viceroy (governor) in India.
  • Qutb-ud-din Aibak was a trusted slave-general of Ghori and played a key role in expanding and consolidating Turkish power in India.
  • After Muhammad Ghori’s death in 1206 AD, Aibak declared independence and became the first Sultan of Delhi, thus founding the Slave Dynasty.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Muhammad Ghori.

Additional Information:

  • Qutb-ud-din Aibak is known for starting the construction of the Qutub Minar.
  • His reign marks the beginning of the Delhi Sultanate in Indian history.

question: The invasion of Mahmud of Ghazni is considered significant because it:
option_1: Resulted in permanent settlement
option_2: Opened the gateway for future Muslim invasions
option_3: Led to the fall of the Mughal Empire
option_4: Introduced new architectural techniques
solution:
• The invasions of Mahmud of Ghazni are considered historically significant because they opened the gateway for future Muslim invasions into India.
  • Though Mahmud did not establish a permanent empire in India, his 17 successful raids between 1000 and 1027 AD exposed the lack of unity among Indian rulers and weakened major kingdoms.
  • This paved the way for later invaders like Muhammad Ghori, who ultimately laid the foundation of Muslim rule in India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Opened the gateway for future Muslim invasions.

Additional Information:

  • Mahmud’s repeated invasions created a psychological and political precedent for future rulers.
  • His campaigns demonstrated the military vulnerability of North Indian kingdoms.

question: The Ghaznavid dynasty was based in present-day:
solution:
• The Ghaznavid dynasty was based in present-day Afghanistan, with its capital at Ghazni.
  • Founded by Alptegin and expanded by Subuktagin and Mahmud of Ghazni, the dynasty ruled parts of Central Asia, Iran, and Northwestern India.
  • Ghazni (in modern Afghanistan) served as the center of administration, culture, and military operations during their rule.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Afghanistan.

Additional Information:

  • Mahmud of Ghazni made Ghazni a center of Islamic learning and art.
  • The Ghaznavids ruled from the 10th to the 12th century.

question: The Delhi Sultanate was established after the invasions of:
solution:
• The Delhi Sultanate was established after the invasions of Muhammad Ghori, particularly after his victory in the Second Battle of Tarain (1192 AD).
  • Muhammad Ghori did not rule India directly but left his trusted general Qutb-ud-din Aibak in charge of Indian territories.
  • After Ghori's death in 1206 AD, Aibak declared independence and became the first Sultan of Delhi, founding the Slave Dynasty.
  • This marked the beginning of Muslim rule in India, formally known as the Delhi Sultanate.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Muhammad Ghori.

Additional Information:

  • The Delhi Sultanate lasted from 1206 to 1526 AD and included five ruling dynasties.
  • The first dynasty was the Mamluk (Slave) Dynasty, followed by Khilji, Tughlaq, Sayyid, and Lodi dynasties.

question: Qutb Minar was initiated by Qutb-ud-din Aibak and completed by:
solution:
• The construction of the Qutb Minar was initiated by Qutb-ud-din Aibak in 1199 AD, shortly after becoming the first Sultan of Delhi.
  • However, Aibak could only complete the base of the minar.
  • The remaining storeys were completed by his successor and son-in-law, Iltutmish.
  • The Qutb Minar stands as a symbol of victory and Islamic rule in India and is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Iltutmish.

Additional Information:

  • The Qutb Minar is located in Delhi and is 73 meters high.
  • Later, Firoz Shah Tughlaq carried out some repairs and additions to the structure.

question: Which ruler fought against Mahmud of Ghazni to defend the Somnath temple?
solution:
• The ruler who fought against Mahmud of Ghazni to defend the Somnath temple during the 1025–26 AD invasion was Bhima I.
  • Bhima I was the Solanki ruler of Gujarat, and the Somnath temple lay within his territory.
  • However, Mahmud’s invasion was swift and forceful; Bhima I fled the region, and the temple was looted and destroyed.
  • Despite resistance, the defense could not withstand Ghazni's army, and the temple's wealth was taken back to Ghazni.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Bhima I.

Additional Information:

  • The Somnath temple was rebuilt multiple times after its destruction by Mahmud.
  • Bhima I was also known for his role in reviving temple architecture in Gujarat later.

question: The Turkish invasions exposed the weakness of:
option_2: Decentralized and fragmented Indian kingdoms
solution:
• The Turkish invasions, especially by Mahmud of Ghazni and Muhammad Ghori, exposed the weakness of decentralized and fragmented Indian kingdoms.
  • During the 10th–12th centuries, North India lacked political unity, with several small kingdoms and regional powers competing among themselves.
  • These disunited states failed to form a collective defense against the well-organized and determined Turkish forces.
  • This fragmentation made it easier for foreign invaders to penetrate and establish control.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Decentralized and fragmented Indian kingdoms.

Additional Information:

  • This period's lack of unity directly led to the success of the Delhi Sultanate’s establishment in 1206 AD.
  • Many Indian rulers underestimated the strategic strength and persistence of the invaders.

question: What was the main difference between Mahmud of Ghazni and Muhammad Ghori?
option_1: Mahmud established a kingdom, Ghori didn’t
option_2: Ghori aimed to establish permanent rule, Mahmud came to loot
option_3: Mahmud was peaceful, Ghori was violent
option_4: Ghori was defeated by Rajputs, Mahmud wasn’t
solution:
• The main difference between Mahmud of Ghazni and Muhammad Ghori lies in their intentions regarding India.
  • Mahmud of Ghazni invaded India 17 times (1000–1027 AD) mainly to loot temples and accumulate wealth for his empire in Ghazni.
  • In contrast, Muhammad Ghori came with the clear aim of establishing permanent rule in India.
  • Ghori founded political control through battles like the Second Battle of Tarain (1192 AD) and laid the foundation for the Delhi Sultanate.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Ghori aimed to establish permanent rule, Mahmud came to loot.

Additional Information:

  • After Ghori’s death, his general Qutb-ud-din Aibak became the first Sultan of Delhi.
  • Mahmud never stayed in India; he always returned to Ghazni after every invasion.

question: Who among the following ruled Ghazni after Mahmud's death?
solution:
• After the death of Mahmud of Ghazni in 1030 AD, he was succeeded by his son Masud I.
  • Masud became the Sultan of Ghazni and tried to maintain the empire his father had built.
  • However, unlike Mahmud, Masud failed to preserve the strength and stability of the Ghaznavid Empire.
  • His reign saw internal dissent and growing external threats, leading to a decline in Ghazni's power.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Masud.

Additional Information:

  • Masud was eventually defeated and imprisoned by his own brother.
  • The Ghaznavid Empire began to weaken significantly after Mahmud’s death.

question: After Muhammad Ghori’s death, who established the Slave Dynasty in India?
solution:
• After the death of Muhammad Ghori in 1206 AD, his trusted general Qutb-ud-din Aibak declared independence and established the Slave Dynasty in India.
  • Qutb-ud-din Aibak became the first Sultan of Delhi and is credited with founding the Delhi Sultanate.
  • He was originally a slave (Mamluk) who rose to power through merit and loyalty, hence the dynasty is called the Mamluk or Slave Dynasty.
  • His reign marked the beginning of Muslim rule as an independent power in India.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Qutb-ud-din Aibak.

Additional Information:

  • Qutb-ud-din Aibak began the construction of the Qutub Minar.
  • He ruled from 1206 to 1210 AD, and after his death, Iltutmish succeeded him.

question: The Turkish invasions were facilitated by the lack of:
option_1: Strong cavalry in India
option_2: Internal conflicts and absence of central power
solution:
• The Turkish invasions of India were greatly facilitated by the lack of political unity and the absence of a strong central authority.
  • During the period of these invasions (10th–12th centuries), North India was divided into many small, often conflicting kingdoms, which weakened collective defense.
  • These internal rivalries and fragmentation made it easier for well-organized and determined Turkish forces to penetrate and conquer Indian territories.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Internal conflicts and absence of central power.

Additional Information:

  • The Rajput rulers, though brave, were often more focused on local rivalries than forming unified resistance against invaders.
  • This allowed invaders like Mahmud of Ghazni and Muhammad Ghori to succeed.

question: The Turkish invaders introduced which new feature in warfare?
option_3: Horse archery and mounted cavalry
solution:
• The Turkish invaders introduced horse archery and fast-moving mounted cavalry as a revolutionary feature in Indian warfare.
  • Their cavalry was highly mobile, skilled in shooting arrows while riding, which gave them a tactical advantage over the relatively slower and less organized Indian armies.
  • In contrast, Indian armies relied more on elephants and infantry, which were powerful but less flexible in battle.
  • This new warfare strategy helped the Turks win against larger Indian forces.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Horse archery and mounted cavalry.

Additional Information:

  • The use of composite bows and hit-and-run tactics made Turkish armies effective in open-field battles.
  • Their speed and coordination often overwhelmed traditional Indian defenses.

question: What was the capital of Muhammad Ghori before his Indian campaigns?
solution:
• Before launching his Indian campaigns, Muhammad Ghori’s capital was Ghor, located in modern-day central Afghanistan.
  • He belonged to the Ghurid dynasty, which was centered in the Ghor region, and hence is known as Muhammad of Ghor.
  • From Ghor, he expanded eastward into Ghazni, Multan, and eventually into northern India.
  • His rule later extended to Lahore and Delhi, but Ghor remained his original base.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Ghor.

Additional Information:

  • After taking control of Ghazni from the Ghaznavids, he used it as a strategic base for Indian expeditions.
  • His Indian territories were later governed by generals like Qutb-ud-din Aibak.

question: Which factor greatly helped Turkish success in India?
option_2: Unity among Indian kings
option_3: Use of superior military organization
solution:
• One of the key reasons for Turkish success in India was their superior military organization and strategy.
  • The Turkish armies were well-disciplined, had centralized command, and used mounted archers with great effectiveness.
  • Their military tactics included rapid mobility, surprise attacks, and battlefield coordination, which Indian forces lacked.
  • Indian kingdoms, in contrast, were disunited and followed traditional methods without modern warfare innovation.
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Use of superior military organization.

Additional Information:

  • Turkish forces often used light cavalry, composite bows, and swift communication.
  • Their commanders like Mahmud of Ghazni and Muhammad Ghori were seasoned strategists.
